What did Emily Graham Ferguson say?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Emma Roberts
Address: Handsworth, Saskatchewan
Birthplace: Ruthven, Ontario

1. DOMESTIC UTILITY
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1903
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Regina, Saskatchewan
   How far had you been living before that? Regina, Saskatchewan
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
   How far was it to your nearest store? Thirty miles to Canada
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, tea, starch, salt, pepper, spices

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Fair Price and Armstrong's, grown in Canada
   In what quantities did you buy it? From 10 to 150 lbs
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $4.50
   How much did you use Graham flour? 7 lbs
   Whole wheat flour? 10 lbs
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   No; far away? 30 miles
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, whole wheat, Farina
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
   How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 cts.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 45c to 50c.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwardsburg.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs.

At what price? About 90¢.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? milked.

Butter? Made it.

Eggs? Had them.

What was the price of butter? 12¢ to 13¢.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork & beef.

How did you get fresh meat? Killed at home.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Dry salt & brine cured.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not much later.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Game birds.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? No meat.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

I do not notice much difference except that we buy most canned goods and bakers bread.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

We brought 2 car-loads of live stock—horses etc from Ontario when we came—our nearest town and station was Arolo—30 miles distant. I am sorry my memory is not good enough to answer all the questionnaire.

Sonia Rolufs

The Rolufs came from near Tweed, Ont.

Fred and I were married in March in 1903.

We were the 1st settlers west of moose river. It was 2 years before we had any neighbor women—several unmarried men homesteaders to bake bread for us. There were no trees near us. The men hunted logs and wood for 1/2 mile.

C.R.
I do not notice much difference except that we buy our canned goods and tobacco there.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of keeping them here? (Give as many dates as and places.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries in Ontario when we came—our nearest town and station were Ancaster—30 miles distant. Gain any buying experience? We bought a brood of sheep—summer it from the Mohawk farm near Tavistock. We were the last settlers west of Mooreville—several unannounced before we had any neighbors women—several unmarried men—promised to take bread for new families—dogs and men—there were no turn rows—no work for 12 months—e.g.
